docs.lead_paragraph: In April 2001, researchers from the New York Medical College and the National Institutes of Health announced electrifying news for heart surgeons and their patients: stem cells from bone marrow, injected into the damaged hearts of mice, had morphed into the special cardiac muscle cells that the body cannot replace after a heart attack. The researchers held out the hope that the procedure could be applied to people, too. The findings underlined a basic premise of stem cell therapy, that it will work before the cells and their elaborate control systems are fully understood -- just put stem cells in the right place in the body, and they will do the rest.

headline.main: The Uncertain Science of Growing Heart Cells

docs.abstract: Four years after study in which doctors found that stem cells from bone marrow injected into damaged hearts of mice could morph into cells that body cannot replace after heart attack, treatment has yet to demonstrate whether it will fulfill its promise; it has touched off sharp debate among clinicians as to whether therapy is ready to be taken to people; ten human trials of marrow-to-heart approach have been conducted in clinics around world, all but one with positive results, but overall improvement in patients' heart function has been modest; original research is under criticism from scientists who have tried without success to reproduce it; approach, if it works, would be leading example of regenerative medicine, idea that best way to repair body is with its own system of cells and signaling molecules; difficulties of heart research do not dash hopes for regenerative medicine, but simply suggest that stem cell treatments may require years to come to fruition; details of various trials discussed; photo; illustration of procedure (M)
docs.snippet: A heart treatment using stem cells of bone marrow has touched off sharp differences as to whether it is ready to be taken to people.

docs.lead_paragraph: PAUL LIVERT of Oceanside has had to dig deep into his pockets for prescription drugs. Last year, he said, he shelled out $2,643 on a variety of medications for the kinds of ailments that come with reaching age 84. ''There's a blood thinner, pills for poor circulation, a slow thyroid, arthritis and a potassium deficiency,'' said Mr. Livert, a retired musician.

headline.main: When Prescriptions Cost Less, Who Pays?

docs.abstract: Article on Nassau Rx card, discount drug plan administered by Caremark RX of Nashville that saves residents of Nassau County, NY, about 20 percent on commonly prescribed name-brand and generic drugs; county officials say those who benefit most are 350,000 residents who lack or have inadequate health insurance or drug coverage; pharmacists argue that price breaks eat into their already lean profit margins; photos (M)
docs.snippet: PAUL LIVERT of Oceanside has had to dig deep into his pockets for prescription drugs. Last year, he said, he shelled out $2,643 on a variety of medications for the kinds of ailments that come with reaching age 84.     ''There's a blood thinner, pills...

docs.lead_paragraph: Zacaria Martínez is not sure how he survived the fire that swept through his prison cell, packed almost to the roof with inmates, killing nearly everyone inside. The only explanation he has is that it was ''at the hands of God.'' Inside the overcrowded prison here early Monday, a battle broke out in a cell known as Vietnam, the authorities said. Shots were fired and punches flew. Mattresses, machetes and other objects sailed through the air before a burst of flame came, then torrents of black, choking smoke.

headline.main: After Prison Horror, Dominican Republic Plans a Study

docs.abstract: Survivors describe inferno inside Dominican prison as gang battle erupted into fire that killed 136 prisoners; photo; diagram; map; government names investigation commission; human rights workers say prison overcrowding in Dominican Republic is among worst in hemisphere; Higuey prison was built to house 80 inmates but held 426 on day of fire (M)
docs.snippet: The Dominican government has appointed a commission to investigate a deadly fire that killed 136 prisoners.

byline.original: By RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD; Nicholas Confessore contributed reporting from New York for this article

docs.lead_paragraph: The dozens of letters, phone calls and e-mail messages I've received since writing my recent columns on total knee replacement and pain management reveal that I struck a chord. Some readers chastised me for scaring potential patients away from this surgery, which, when healing is completed, can greatly enhance quality of life. But many others praised me for ''telling it like it is'' about an often painful and difficult recovery that surgeons don't warn patients about.

headline.main: A Fight for Full Disclosure of the Possible Pain

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column discusses post-operative pain from knee replacement surgery; calls for doctors to tell patients truth about what recovery period may entail and allow them to make educated decision about operation; column holds that without adequate information patients cannot plan for future and prepare for recovery; overall problems with approach to pain management discussed; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: Sharing lessons from painful recoveries from knee surgery.

docs.lead_paragraph: Regular use of low-dose aspirin does not prevent first heart attacks in women younger than 65, as it does in men, a 10-year study of healthy women has found. The participants in the Women's Health Study who took 100 milligrams of aspirin every other day were no less likely to suffer heart attacks than the participants in another group who took placebos. Each group had about 20,000 members.

headline.main: Aspirin Is Found to Protect Women From Strokes, Not Heart Attacks

docs.abstract: Women's Health Study, which was sponsored in part by National Heart, Lung and Blood Institute, finds that regular use of low-dose aspirin by women under 65 years of age does not prevent first heart attacks as it does in men; study does show, however, that low-dose aspirin helps protect women against ischemic stroke; findings, which were presented at American College of Cardiology meeting, may refocus attention on overall heart and cardiovascular health for women; researchers stress need for women to know their risk for cardiovascular illness and work with their doctors to explore preventive measures when appropriate (M)
docs.snippet: Regular use of low-dose aspirin does not prevent first heart attacks in women, as it does in men, a 10-year study of healthy women has found.

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
